subject: Re: Problem with simple test case
msgSnippet: If you re going to test lots of servlets, consider writing fake HttpServletRequest and HttpServletResponse. The response could f.i. provide a fake Printwriter
messageBody:
If you're going to test lots of servlets, consider writing fake
HttpServletRequest and HttpServletResponse.
The response could f.i. provide a fake Printwriter that records
what's printed on him.
Test the doGet() method as any other method. Make a new HelloWorld()
and call its doGet() with your fake request and response. After
execution you can inspect the changes in request and response. In
your case : get the fake writer and check the printed lines.
Your tests will run without the server running. You're only testing
the class and not f.i. the configuration of the server.

The fake requests and responses can be found on the internet,
google "MockHttpServletRequest".
I took the sourcecode from http://mockrunner.sourceforge.net/ and
modified(simplified) the code for my use.

Hope it helps,

Bart

> public class HelloWorld extends HttpServlet {
> public void doGet(HttpServletRequest request,
> HttpServletResponse response)
> throws IOException, ServletException
> {
> response.setContentType("text/html");
> PrintWriter out = response.getWriter();
> out.println("<html>");
> out.println("<head>");
> //out.println("<title>Hello World!</title>");
> out.println("</head>");
> out.println("<body>");
> out.println("<h1>Hello World!</h1>");
> out.println("</body>");
> out.println("</html>");
> }
> public void doPost(HttpServletRequest request,
> HttpServletResponse response)
> throws IOException, ServletException {
> doGet(request, response);
> }
> }
>
> *********************TEST CASE BEGIN*********************
> public class HelloWorldTest extends ServletTestCase{
>
> public void testDoGet() {
> HelloWorld hw = new HelloWorld();
> try {
> hw.doGet(request,response);
> }catch (Exception e) { }
> }
>
> public void endDoGet(WebResponse theResponse) {
> String expected = "<html><head></head><body><h1>Hello World!
> </h1></body></html>";
> String actual = theResponse.getText();
>
> assertEquals(expected,actual);
> }
> }
>
